turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Wait a minute!  What am I worried about?  Otho, you can't even change a tire!

turns.speaker: OTHO
turns.text: I'll need something personal of theirs.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: Their wedding clothes.

turns.speaker: OTHO
turns.text: Their wedding clothes.

turns.speaker: LYDIA
turns.text: <u>Adam</u>!  <u>Adam</u>!

turns.speaker: OTHO
turns.text: As flies the lizard Serpent fell; As goblin vizard, At the spell Of pale wizard, Sinks to hell; The buried, dead, and slain... Rise again.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: The injection will ease the pain and swelling, Mr. Gardiner.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I understand. I've seen it done before.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Now, you'll barely feel this. It won't hurt at all.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: You were wrong, it did hurt.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: But not for long...

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: It's good that there was no apparent damage to the bone.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I think so, too.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: However, with injuries such as this, I have run into minor hemorrhaging, which really isn't too serious at the time, but can cause secondary problems if not looked after.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: You can pull your trousers up, now.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Oh, fine.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Just to take the proper precautions, Mr. Gardiner, I'd recommend we take you downstairs and X-ray your leg.  ... By the way, Mr. Gardiner, I would like to ask you something straight out.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: ... Straight out?

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Yes. Are you planning on making any sort of claim against the Rand's?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Claim...? ... Oh, claim, that's what Thomas asked me.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Thomas? Who's Thomas?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Thomas Franklin, an attorney.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: An attorney?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Then you wish to handle this matter through your attorneys?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: There's no need for a claim, the garden is a healthy one.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Oh, I see...  ... Well, then... You're a very funny man, Mr. Gardiner. You caught me off guard, I must admit...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Good, keep your weight off that leg, Mr. Gardiner. In fact, it would be best if you could stay here for a day or two, if that would be would be possible. Since Benjamin became ill we have our own hospital downstairs. I can promise you the finest in care, unless, of course, you would prefer to go elsewhere.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, I could stay here. Thank you.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Fine. Would you like me to speak to your personal physician?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: I'll send Wilson up to take you for X-rays, Mr. Gardiner. Feel free to use the telephone, and please let me know if you have any discomfort.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, I will.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: ... And please call me Robert.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Robert. I will.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Chauncey, there you are. What are you doing on that leg?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: It's fine today, Robert.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Shame on you, Chauncey - you should let me be the judge of that.  Please, sit in the chair.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: I swear, Chauncey, between you and Benjamin, I've got my hands full...  ... Say, that is coming along, the swelling has gone down considerably...  ... Any pain here?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Robert. But it's not bad.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: ... Benjamin has been hounding me to allow him to address the annual meeting of his Financial Institute today, but obviously, the strain would be impossible... How about here, Chauncey, any soreness?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Hardly any, Robert.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: ... Were you going somewhere?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No, Robert.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: ... Oh.  ... My God, I only wish that Benjamin had your recuperative powers... Anyway, the President offered to sit in for Ben at the meeting, quite a nice gesture, I felt. He's due here soon, I believe.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Robert. I know about the President.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: ... Oh? You've heard?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. Ben called me. He wants me to meet the President.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: He does, does he?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Ben told me to be in his room at ten o'clock.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Why, that's terrific, Chauncey.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: How do I know when it's ten o'clock?

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: ... It's five of, you'd best get on in there.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Thank you, Robert.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I would like to walk today.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Hell yes - walk. You're meeting the President, aren't you?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Oh, really?

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: ... He's gone, Chauncey.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Robert. I have seen it before. It happens to old people.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Yes, I suppose that's true.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Will you be leaving now, Robert?

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: In a day or two, yes.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Eve is going to stay. The house will not be closed.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: ... You've become quite a close friend of Eve's - haven't you Mr...  ... Chance...?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I love Eve very much.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: I see...  ... And you are really a gardener, aren't you?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Robert - I am.  I'll go tell Eve about Ben now, Robert.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: I know exactly what you mean. Today the businessman is at the mercy of kid-lawyers from the SEC. All they want to do is regulate our natural growth! It's happening across the country!

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: To everyone, I'm afraid. The Government controls are so restricting that the Medical Profession, as we know it, is being legislated out of existence.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Of course! By kid-lawyers!

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: ... No, of course you don't. Excuse me for being so presumptuous. No man knows everything about another man - however, very few are honest enough to admit it.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: That is so true. You're different, Chauncey... Quite different than most men.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Some pain is to be expected...  ... And I think what would be best for the two of you is a good night's rest.  ... It's late, I'm afraid it's time for my patients to prepare for bed.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: We have common foes, Chauncey - kid lawyers and our physician!

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: And you, Benjamin, must be strong and brave for me. Turn over, please.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: In a minute, Robert - in a minute... Chauncey, I would like to ask a favor of you...

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: No more, Robert... No more needles...

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: It's not good, Ben - I'm sure you can feel it.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: I know, Robert... But, strangely enough, I don't feel too bad about now... I feel all right... I guess it's easier... knowing Chauncey is here... to take care of things...

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Good God, Eve - you'll freeze out here.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I wanted some fresh air, Robert. How is Mr. Gardiner?

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: A rather large contusion, but I don't feel there is any serious damage. I'd like to keep an eye on him, though - I suggested that he stay here for a couple of days.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Stay here? Is that necessary?

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Not necessary, but preferable. I don't think he'll be a bother, he seems like a most refreshing sort of man.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Yes, he is different... Not the kind of person one usually meets in Washington.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: How true. Mr. Gardiner may be a welcome change of pace.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: He's very intense, and internal, don't you think?

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: At times, yes. But that's not an uncommon reaction to such an accident. Actually, I found him to have quite a sense of humor.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Good. It might be pleasant for a couple of days.  ... Robert... Is there any improvement...?

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: No, Eve... I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: ... Eve - this has been an exhausting day for Ben...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... But he's...?

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: He's resting comfortably now. There's no cause for alarm, yet...

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: ... He walked off...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Chauncey is so sensitive... He was overcome with grief...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... Do you think we should look for him?

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: I don't think so, he should be along soon...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I wish he were here...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: We have to find him, Robert - he could be lost, something may have happened, we can't leave him!

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: You really care for him, don't you, Eve?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I do - we do - both of us, Ben and I feel so much for Chauncey...

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: I think we'd better go look for him.  David!

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: ... And he told us that he had been living there since he was a child, working as a gardener. He showed us a room in the garage, where he said he stayed, and I... Well, I didn't really believe him, of course - but why the act?

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: I have no idea...

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Another thing that baffles me, Doctor - what was his connection with the deceased? Major financial dealings, obviously - but our firm has no record of any such transactions.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Hmmm. You say he showed you his garden?

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Well, he said it was his, he walked us through it.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: I see.  Mr. Franklin, I must ask you and Miss Hayes to keep this incident with Mr. Gardiner to yourselves. There's no telling what he was involved in, and the matter may be extremely confidential. So please, not a word.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Of course, Doctor, I understand.

turns.speaker: ALLENBY
turns.text: Fine. Thank you, Mr. Franklin.

turns.speaker: FRANKLIN
turns.text: Certainly, glad to be of help.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Gentlemen, I didn't call you here at such an hour to make accusations, I just want to explore the possibilities. Now, I have three questions; Is the man a foreign agent? Or, have we suddenly found that our methods of gathering data are grossly inefficient? Or, thirdly, have the man's files been destroyed? Now, I'd like some answers.

turns.speaker: BALDWIN
turns.text: Gardiner is not a foreign agent, there are now sixteen countries investigating the man. We can rule that out.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Very well... Can we rule out inefficiency...?

turns.speaker: BALDWIN
turns.text: I don't think that's entirely true, Grover.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: And what do the boys around Intelligence think?

turns.speaker: BALDWIN
turns.text: Well, Mr. President... They don't quite know what to think.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Gentlemen, needless to say, there is going to be a full Congressional investigation of your respective operations.  Good night.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Do you know Raphael?

turns.speaker: BILLINGS
turns.text: No sir, I don't believe I do.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Oh. I have a message for him.

turns.speaker: BILLINGS
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: A Black man gave me the message.

turns.speaker: BILLINGS
turns.text: Well, I still don't believe I know the man, Mr. Gardiner. Now, hold still.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I understand. I've never seen anything like this on television.

turns.speaker: BILLINGS
turns.text: Please, hold still, Mr. Gardiner.

turns.speaker: MRS. AUBREY
turns.text: Mr. Gardiner, I have a telephone call for you. Sidney Courtney, the financial editor of the Washington Post.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MRS. AUBREY
turns.text: Would you care to take it, sir?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MRS. AUBREY
turns.text: Oh, Mr. Gardiner, I've been looking all over.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Oh, yes.

turns.speaker: MRS. AUBREY
turns.text: Morton Hull, the producer of 'This Evening' just called.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, I have seen that show on television.

turns.speaker: MRS. AUBREY
turns.text: Of course. They would like you to appear on the show tonight. The Vice President was scheduled, but he had to cancel, and they asked if you would be interested.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I would like to be on that show.

turns.speaker: MRS. AUBREY
turns.text: Fine. They felt that since you had such close ties with the President, you would be a splendid choice.  ... Can I help you? Are you looking for something?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No. I like this attic very much.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... Won't you let us do something for you? Your leg should be examined, we could take you to a hospital.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: There's no need for a hospital.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Why, there certainly is. You must see a doctor, I insist on it. Please, let us take you.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I hope you're comfortable.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I am.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: These can be such trying situations everyone seems to make such a to-do over a simple little accident. Of course, they can be very frightening, and I must apologize for David, he's never had an accident before.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. He's a very careful driver.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... Why, yes, he is... Is your leg feeling any better?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: It's feeling better, but it's still very sore.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I see.  ... Say, would you mind seeing our family doctor?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Your family doctor?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Yes. My husband has been very ill. His doctor and nurses are staying with us. Those hospitals can be so impersonal - why, it might be hours before you are treated...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I agree.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Fine, it will save a lot of unnecessary fuss and it will be so much more pleasant for you...  David, we'll just go on home. Jeffrey, would you call and let them know?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Would you care for a drink?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. Thank you.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I would like to watch television.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh? Certainly...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh, by the way - I'm Eve Rand.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Hello, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: May I ask your name?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: My name is Chance.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Pardon me, was that Mr. Chance?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No. I'm a gardener.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh... Mr. Gardiner... Mr. Chauncey Gardiner... You're not related to Basil and Perdita Gardiner are you?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No, Eve. I'm not related to Basil and Perdita.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh. Well, they're just a wonderful couple, we've been friends for years. We visit their island quite often.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Did you lose something?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I lost my remote control.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh... Well, I'm very sorry...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... I'll feel so relieved after Dr. Allenby examines your leg. After that, David can run you on home, or to your office or wherever you'd prefer...  ... Is there anything special you would like to watch?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I like to watch. This is fine.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I can see that it must be very important for you to stay informed of all the latest events.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I admire that in a person. As for myself, I find there is so much to assimilate that it can become quite muddling at times...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Won't your injury prevent you from attending to business, Mr. Gardiner?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No. It won't do that.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... Would you like us to notify anyone for you?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No. The Old Man died and Louise left.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I hope that staying here won't be an inconvenience for you.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No. I like it here.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh, I know exactly what you mean. I sometimes enjoy puttering around myself, such a pleasant way to forget one's troubles.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I am a very good gardener.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Chauncey, I wanted to tell you how dreadful I feel about the accident today, but that I'm delighted that you are staying with us.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Thank you, Eve - I like this house very much.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... And Ben is just mad about you - you've lifted his spirits so - it's just... Well, it's just a real pleasure having you with us.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Ben is very ill, Eve - I've seen that before.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Yes... I know, Chauncey.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I like Ben very much... He reminds me of the Old Man...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: He does...?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. Are you going to leave and close the house when he dies?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... Why... No, I don't think so...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: That's good.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... Good night, Chauncey.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Good night, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Chauncey!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Hello, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Your leg must be getting better.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. It's feeling much better now.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Good. I'm glad to hear that.  ... How did you like meeting the President?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Fine. He's very nice.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Yes, he is. I'm sorry I didn't get to see him.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... Chauncey... Last night you mentioned an old man, that died.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Was he a relative? Or an intimate friend?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: He was a very wealthy man, he looked after me since I was young.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh, I see... Your mentor, perhaps?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: ... Mentor...?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Forgive me, Chauncey - I didn't mean to pry. You must have been very close to him.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I was.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'm sorry...  ... And what about Louise? YOU mentioned that she had gone, were you close to her also?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I liked Louise very much. She was his maid.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh, his maid!... Stupid me, I thought perhaps she was someone that you may have been romantically involved with.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Oh, no. She brought me my meals.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: What is that?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Our greenhouse.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Oh, I like that very much.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Yes, so do we.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... I'm...  ... I'm very grateful that you're here, Chauncey...  ... With us ...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: So am I, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'll be all right, Chauncey you go ahead with Mrs. Aubrey...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Eve. You'll be all right.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Chauncey...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Hello, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Chauncey, I just wanted to wish you well. I know you'll be smashing.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Thank you, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: And Benjamin sends along his best wishes.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: How is Ben feeling?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: He's tired, Chauncey - but he's going to watch you tonight. We'll both be watching.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: That's good. I like to watch, too.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I know you do - you and your television...  ... Good luck, Chauncey.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... You don't happen to have a tuxedo in your suitcase, do you?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No, thank you.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh. Well, we can fix up one of Ben's for you tomorrow night. Sophie insists an Black Tie.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... I have very few friends, Chauncey... And Benjamin's friends are all quite a bit older...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... Good night, Chauncey.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Good night, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Chauncey! Have you seen the papers?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No, Eve. I don't read the papers.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Well, it seems you've been described as one of the architects of the President's speech. And your own comments from the 'This Evening' show are quoted side by side with the President's.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I like the President. He is a very nice man.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I know...  ... So are you, Chauncey ...  ... Do you mind my being here, like this?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No, Eve. I like you to be here.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... You know, Chauncey... I want us to be...  I want us... You and I to become... close... I want us to become very close, you know...?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Eve. I know that.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... I'm grateful to you, Chauncey... I would have opened to you with a touch, and you know that...  ... But you're so strong - I can trust myself with you. I'm glad, Chauncey - I'm glad that you showed so much restraint...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Eve. I'm very glad that you didn't open.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I know you are, Chauncey...  ... You conquer a woman from within herself, you infuse in her the need and desire and the longing for your love.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. That could be true.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... I guess I may as well be honest about my feelings, Chauncey, as I know you are I am in love with you... I love you and I want you... And I know that you know it and I'm grateful that you've decided to wait until... Until...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I've never seen anyone handle the media as well as you, Chauncey. You're so cool and detached - almost as if you were born to it.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Thank you, Eve.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Chauncey, this is Mr. Dennis Watson of the State Department.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Hello, Dennis.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Chauncey, where have you been? I was afraid you got bored and left, or that you were with some mysterious woman.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No. I was with a man. We went upstairs.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Upstairs? Chauncey, you're always involved in some sort of discussion...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: He was very ill, I stayed with him for a while.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: It must be the punch, and it is stuffy in here -- I feel it a little myself. You're an angel, my dear - thank God there are still men like you around to give aid and comfort.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I feel so close to you, so safe with you, Chauncey...  ... And Benjamin understands that, dearest... He understands and accepts my feelings for you...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Eve. Ben is very wise.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... Come in, Chauncey - please come in...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I just don't excite you at all... I don't know what you want... I don't know what you like...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I like to watch.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: To watch...? To watch me...?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I like to watch.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... Is that all you want...?  ... To watch me...?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. It's very good, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... But I've never done...  ... You mean...? When... When... When I do it? ... When I touch myself...?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Dearest, you uncoil my wants; desire flows within me, and when you watch me my passion dissolves it. You set me free. I reveal myself to myself and I am drenched and purged.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: That's very interesting, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Chauncey! Chauncey!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Hello, Eve.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oh, Chauncey, darling... Where have you been? We thought we'd lost you - we've been looking all over!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I've been looking for you, too, Eve.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Hello, Mr. Gardiner. This is Sid Courtney, Washington Post.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Hello, Sid.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: I'm sorry to disturb you, Mr. Gardiner, I know you must be very busy.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No. I'm not busy.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Then, I'll be brief. I covered the President's speech at the Financial Institute today, and since the Post would like to be as exact as possible, we would appreciate your comments on the meeting that took place between Mr. Rand, the President and yourself.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: The President is a nice person. I enjoyed it very much.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Good, sir. And so, it seems, did the President - but we would like to have some facts; such as, uh... What exactly is the relationship between yourself and that of the First American Financial Corporation?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I think you should ask Mr. Rand that.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: Of course. But since he is ill I'm taking the liberty of asking you.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, that is correct. I think you should ask Mr. Rand that.

turns.speaker: COURTNEY
turns.text: I see. Then one more quick question, Mr. Gardiner; since we at the Post would like to, uh - update our profile on you - what exactly is your business?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I have nothing more to say.

turns.speaker: HULL
turns.text: Mr. Gardiner, I'm Morton Hull, the producer of 'This Evening.'

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Hello, Morton.

turns.speaker: HULL
turns.text: Of course, Mr. Gardiner, the fact that you occupy such a position in the world of finance makes you ideally suited to provide our millions of viewers with an explanation of this nation's economic crisis.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: HULL
turns.text: Do you realize, Mr. Gardiner, that more people will be watching you tonight than all those who have seen theater plays in the last forty years?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. It's a very good show.

turns.speaker: HULL
turns.text: I'm glad you like it, Mr. Gardiner.

turns.speaker: DENNIS' VOICE
turns.text: Can you see well?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, very well, thank you.

turns.speaker: DENNIS' VOICE
turns.text: Do you like it?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. It's very tiny, but it's good.

turns.speaker: DENNIS' VOICE
turns.text: ... Are you sure you like it?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, I do, it's very good.

turns.speaker: DENNIS' VOICE
turns.text: Really? Really!!!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Do you need a doctor? I could call Robert...

turns.speaker: DENNIS' VOICE
turns.text: I don't want Robert.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: DENNIS' VOICE
turns.text: Your foot! Give me your foot!!

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: You must sit with us, my friend, we have much to discuss.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I agree.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: How is my dear friend Benjamin feeling?

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: Regretfully, Mrs. Rand - I shall yield the pleasure of your company to others.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Eve. I shall yield too.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: I'm sorry we haven't met sooner, Mr. Gardiner. I had the pleasure of seeing you on television last night and I listened with great interest to your down-to-earth philosophy. I'm not surprised that it was so quickly endorsed by the President.  ... Tell me, Mr. Gardiner, just how serious is Benjamin's illness? I did not want to upset Mrs. Rand by discussing it in detail.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Ben is very ill.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: Yes, so I've heard, a shame... As you know, we in the Soviet Union have the keenest interest in developments of the First American Financial Corporation... We are pleased to hear that you may fill Benjamin's place should he fail to recover.  Be seated, please, Mr. Gardiner.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: ... Mr. Gardiner, I wish to be quite candid - considering the gravity of your economic situation, shouldn't we, the diplomats, and you, the businessman - get together more often?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, I agree, I think so too.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: To exchange our thoughts - what does a Russian know about business? On the other hand, what does an American know about diplomacy?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, I understand.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: And I have noticed in you a certain reticence regarding political issues - so why not a coming together? An interchange of opinion? We may find, my friend, that we are not so far from each other, not so far!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: We are not far...  ... our chairs almost touch.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: Bravo! Bravo! Our chairs are indeed almost touching! And we want to remain seated on them, correct? We don't want them snatched from under us, am I right? Because if one goes, the other goes, and then - boom! Boom! And we are both down before our time, you see? And neither of us wants that, do you agree?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I certainly do.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: Yes. Tell me, Mr. Gardiner - do you by any chance enjoy Krylov's fables? I ask this because there is something... there is something Krylovian about you.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Do you think so? Do you think so?

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: So you know Krylov!

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: So you know your Krylov in Russian, do you? Mr. Gardiner, I must confess I had suspected as much all along - I know an educated man when I meet one!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Oh, good.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: Yes, it is very good!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, it is.  Would you tell me your name again, please?

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: Ho! Ho! A dash of American humor! Vladimar Skrapinov!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I like that name very much.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: And yours, sir - Chauncey Gardiner!  How poetic! Chauncey, a name of uncertain meaning! And Gardiner, a bit of the French, a suggestion of a stroll through the flowers! A beautiful name, my friend!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Eve. That would be good.

turns.speaker: SKRAPINOV
turns.text: We must speak again, Mr. Gardiner, many times!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Welcome to Rand Memorial Hospital, Mr. Gardiner.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: ... I see.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I feel very good in here.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Sure you do. This ward is air tight, I have a little extra oxygen pumped in, keeps my spirits up.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I like that very much.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Failure of the bone marrow to produce red blood cells... Not a damn thing they can do about it. Oh, they can make me comfortable, prolong my life with steroid therapy and transfusions... And what makes my blood boil, what little I have left, that is, Mr. Gardiner - is that it's generally a young person's disease... Here I am, getting on in years and about to die of a young person's disease...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. You look very sick.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: ... We're prisoners, Mr. Gardiner - we're prisoners of tubes and technology.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I agree.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: ... You will join us for dinner, won't you, Mr. Gardiner?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I am very hungry.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: ... So am I, my boy - so am I.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No, thank you. My house has been closed.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Oh. When you say 'Your house has been closed', you mean to say that your business was shut down?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. Shut down and locked by the attorneys.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: What'd I tell you? Kid-lawyers! The S.E.C.! Damn them!

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: That's good, Mr. Gardiner. Or may I call you Chauncey?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. Chauncey is fine.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: And I'm Ben.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Do we have a garden? Hah! Tomorrow, Chauncey, you will see our gardens.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I see. I would like to work in your garden.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: A gardener! Well put, Chauncey excellent! Isn't that what a businessman is? A gardener? A person that makes flinty soil productive with the labor of his own hands, who waters it with the sweat from his own brow, and who creates a place of value for his family and community? Yes, Chauncey, what a brilliant metaphor -- yes, indeed, a productive businessman is a laborer in his own vineyard.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Thank you, Ben. The garden that I left was such a place. Everything which grew there was with the labor of my own hands. I planted seeds and watered them and watched everything grow.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Bravo!

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: But I don't have that any more...  ... All that's left for me now is the room upstairs.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Now, wait a minute, Chauncey you are young, you are healthy, for God's sake don't give up on yourself! You have to fight! You can't let those bastards keep you down! I don't want to hear any more from you about the 'Room Upstairs'. That's where I'm going soon.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: It's a very pleasant room, Ben.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Yes, I'm sure it is. That's what they say, anyway.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No, Ben.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Reluctant to speak, eh, Chauncey? Well, I can understand that. When a man loses everything, anger has a tendency to block out reason for a time. Just give it some thought, work with the idea, I'm sure you'll have plenty to say in a few days.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I could give it some thought, Ben, but my leg is very sore.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: ... Oh?  Robert, take a look, would you?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Chauncey, up and around this morning, are you?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Ben. My leg is not very sore.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Well, that's good news, my boy.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: You're looking much better today, Ben.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Hah! It's all make-up, Chauncey... I asked nurse Teresa to fix me up, I didn't want the President to think I was going to die during our talk.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I understand.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: No one likes a dying man, my boy - because few know what death is. All we know is the terror of it. But you're an exception, Chauncey - that's what I admire in you, your marvelous balance. You don't stagger back and forth between fear and hope - you're a truly peaceful man.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Thank you, Ben.  ... The nurse did a very good job, Ben.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Yes, when I was younger I had thoughts about public office... But I found, Chauncey - that I was able to contribute more as a private citizen... of course, my wealth provided me with considerable influence, but I've tried, believe me, not to misuse that power... It's extremely important, Chauncey, when one is in a position of eminence, that he does not allow himself to become blinded to the needs of the country... The temptations are strong, and I've been labeled a 'kingmaker' by many, but I have tried to stay open to voices of the people... I have tried to remain honest to myself...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I see, Ben.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: ... Maybe one day you shall find yourself in a similar position, Chauncey... Maybe one day...

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: I think what my most insightful friend is saying, Mr. President, is that we welcome the inevitable seasons of nature, yet we are upset by the seasons of our economy.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. That is correct.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: He's a decent fellow, the President, isn't he?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Ben - he is.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: He was quite impressed with your comments, Chauncey - he hears my sort of analysis from everyone, but yours, unfortunately - seldom if ever at all.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I'm glad he came, Ben. It was nice talking to the President.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: ... You know, Chauncey, there's something about you... You're direct, you grasp things quickly and you state them plainly. You don't play games with words to protect yourself. I feel I can speak to you frankly... You know what I was talking to you about last night?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: No, Ben.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Oh, sure you do, the financial assistance program. I think you might be just the man to take charge of such an undertaking. I'd like you to meet with the members of the Board, we'll be able to discuss the matter at greater length at that time.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I understand.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: And, please, Chauncey - don't rush your decision. I know you're not a man to act on the spur of the moment.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Thank you, Ben.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: And now, Chauncey, I'm afraid you must excuse me - I'm very tired all of a sudden.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Certainly, Ben.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Senator Rowley's widow, Sophie, is hosting an evening reception tomorrow evening honoring Ambassador Skrapinov of the Soviet Union... I think it's rather obvious that Robert won't allow me to attend, so - would you go in my place, and escort Eve?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I would like to escort Eve.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Good. Together, the two of you should create quite a stir - I can already hear the gossip.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: ... Chauncey... Chauncey...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes, Ben - are you going to die now?

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: ... I'm about to surrender the Horn of Plenty for the Horn of Gabriel, my boy...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Oh, I see.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: Let me feel the strength in your hand, Chauncey... Let me feel your strength...  Yes, that's good... I hope, Chauncey - I hope that you'll stay with Eve... Take care of her, watch over her, she's a delicate flower, Chauncey...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: A flower...

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: She cares for you and she needs your help, Chauncey... there's much to be looked after...

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I would like to do that.

turns.speaker: RAND
turns.text: ... I've worked very hard and enjoyed my life... I've known success... and I've felt love... My associates, Chauncey - I've talked with them about you... They're eager to meet you... very eager to meet you... I'm very fond of you, Chauncey... And I understand Eve... Tell her that... tell her I'm madly in love with her...

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: We could do it now, we can go upstairs.  ... Please, it's time for us. Come upstairs.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I like to watch.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Watch? You mean just watch me? Doing it alone?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes. I like to watch very much.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Well, if that's what you want, then I want it too.  We can go this way.

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: I want to tell Eve.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Tell Eve? You mean Mrs. Rand?

turns.speaker: CHANCE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Oh, you can tell her later. She'll never miss you in this crowd.
